key_title: Key to the species of Asperula

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Rubiaceae

source.author: Thompson, I.R.
source.title: A revision of Asperula and Galium (Rubieae: Rubiaceae) in Australia
source.citation: From: Thompson, I.R. (2009). A revision of Asperula and Galium (Rubieae: Rubiaceae) in Australia. Muelleria 27:36-112.

leads.lead_text: Leaves and stipules in whorls of 4–9 throughout; plant not or barely climbing
Leaves in pairs and stipules small or absent on upper stems; plant often climbing; north-western Victoria only
Leaves and stipules mostly in whorls of 4, glabrous
Leaves and stipules mostly in whorls of 6–9, variously hairy or glabrous
Leaves and stipules more or less equal; plant herbaceous throughout
Leaves and stipules unequal; plant with woody lower stems and rootstock; rare in east
Leaves obovate, oblanceolate or elliptic, drying dark green to black
Leaves linear to linear lanceolate, drying green
Leaves mostly spreading or deflexed, usually more or less straight; plant drying green or blackish
Leaves mostly suberect, arcuate, curving inwards towards stem (at least in the dried state); plant drying grey-green; north-western Victoria only
Leaves with an almost pungent hyaline tip 0.2–0.5 mm long
Leaves with hyaline tip absent of if present, less than 0.2 mm long
Leaves of stems and major branches greater than 10 mm long and with a length:width ratio greater than 10
Leaves less than 10 mm long or if longer then with a length:width ratio less than 10
Leaves mildly tapering basally (base greater than half of maximum width), with abaxial midrib robust and protruding relative to margins
Leaves moderately to strongly tapering basally (base less than half of maximum width), with abaxial midrib slender and generally recessed relative to margins
Stems glabrous or almost so with up to c. 5 minute prickle-like hairs per mm of stem angle
Stems clearly hairy  usually with greater than 10 minute prickle-like hairs per mm of stem angle, at least near nodes

Leaves generally nearly parallel-sided, at least some with apex recurved or rolled under or obtuse to rounded; abaxial midrib, if hairy, with narrow-based hairs; cymes congested with pedicels generally less than 1 mm long

Leaves usually distinctly narrow-elliptic or oblanceolate with apex not recurved, subacute to acute; abaxial midrib, if hairy, with broad-based hairs; cymes slightly lax with pedicels commonly greater than 1 mm long
Upper surface of leaves with scattered minute hairs; leaves predominantly less than 0.7 mm wide; corolla-tube of female flowers less than 0.5 mm long
Upper surface of leaves glabrous or with only a few hairs near apex and margins; leaves predominantly greater than 0.7 mm wide; corolla-tube of female flowers greater than 0.5 mm long
Leaves generally nearly parallel-sided, often with apex recurved or rolled under; abaxial midrib, if hairy, with narrow-based hairs, needle-like in profile
Leaves usually distinctly narrow-elliptic, narrow-oblanceolate or narrow-obovate, often with apex recurved or rolled; abaxial midrib, if hairy, with broad-based hairs, narrow-triangular in profile
Abaxial midrib glabrous
Abaxial midrib with scattered broad-based hairs

Leaves narrow-cuneate, less than 1.5 mm wide 3 mm from base, with length:width ratio 4–10; larger stems usually with at least one whorl 7- or 8-partite; anthers greater than 0.6–07 mm long (male plants); style 2–2.2 mm long (female plants)

Leaves cuneate, greater than 1.5 mm wide 3 mm from base, with length:width ratio 2–5; stems usually with all whorls 6-partite; anthers 0.4–0.5 mm long (male plants); style 1.2–1.8 mm long (female plants)
